summary: The Marketing Expert presented the results of a market survey that indicated users' most important preferences in remote control features. He discussed trends in fashion that should be incorporated into the prototype design. The User Interface Designer compared the designs of several competitors' remotes to decide which features should be used in their own design. She discussed using voice recognition, an LCD screen, and color to make the device easier to use and to improve its look. The Industrial Designer went over all of the internal components and materials that will be incorporated in the design. He gave a layout of the placement of the components in the device. The group decided to use a rubber or latex material to give the device a spongy feel. He discussed the color and shape of the remote with the group and the placement of the components on the device. The group discussed colors and shapes further, and decided that the remote will be yellow, and perhaps having a fruit-inspired shape. The group decided to use a rechargeable battery and recharging stand. The Project Manager instructed the User Interface Designer and the Industrial Designer to construct the prototype.
actions: The User Interface Designer and the Industrial Designer will build a prototype out of clay for the next meeting.
decisions: The remote will feature a rubber or latex casing. Several shapes will be designed and shown to the public so that the most popular shape is chosen. The remote will be yellow or partially yellow and have an organic shape. The remote will feature speech recognition. The remote will be powered by rechargeable batteries and come with a recharging stand.
problems: The group had difficulty deciding how to incorporate the company's yellow color and the fruit and vegetable trend into the prototype design without the remote seeming overly gimmicky or childish.

ES2005docs.ES2005scen.participant2hBcComponents_design.ppt ------------ Components Design Presented by: Arlo, Industrial Designer Method Look at pre-existing models Reuse the essential components Incorporate new innovations Findings Let’s look inside a (simple) remote control Link to dissected RC Remote control has parts: Outer casing: Board: printed circuits, contact switches Processor: integrated circuit (TA11835 chip) Amplifier: op-amp transistor Transmitter: Infrared LED bulb Our components: casing Our products can be delivered in different cases. The general case is uncurved (flat). A more original case is single curved or even double curved. Furthermore we offer case material supplements, such as plastic, rubber (such as used in anti-RSI stress balls), wood, and titanium (which we also use in our production of space designs). Unfortunately, we can't use the titanium for the double curved cases and latex cases won't allow the use of solar cells as energy source. Energy Source As energy source we offer a basic battery or, more ingenious, a hand dynamo (like you’d find in 50-year-old torches), a kinetic provision of energy (such as in some modern watches that you shake casually to provide energy), or use of solar cells. User Interface For the interface, we are experts on push buttons. In the last decade we have also developed scroll wheels with optional integrated push button (such as in the modern computer mouse), and liquid crystal displays (LCD). Multiple scroll buttons are possible. Note that, if you use a rubber double curved case, you must use rubber push buttons. Electronics For the interface, we are experts on push buttons. In the last decade we have also developed scroll wheels with optional integrated push button (such as in the modern computer mouse), and liquid crystal displays (LCD). Multiple scroll buttons are possible. Note that, if you use a rubber double curved case, you must use rubber push buttons. Chip considerations For the electronics, we can use a simple, a regular or an advanced chip on print. The chip on print includes an infrared sender. Furthermore we have just developed a sample sensor/ sample speaker. Note that a push button requires a simple chip, but a scroll wheel requires minimally a regular chip, which is in a higher price range. The display requires an advanced chip, which in turn is more expensive than the regular chip. Speech Recognition Requires a microphone (cheap) Requires a speech recognition architecture condensed to IC technology. Tradeoffs involve quality vs. complexity. For TV noise cancellation: requires an additional microphone and transmission signal to ASR component. ES2005docs.ES2005scen.participant2hBcWorking_design.ppt ------------ Working Design Presented by: Arlo, Industrial Designer Method Consider input from marketing, UI: What are the basic needs? What novel features can be added? Consider limitations: Budget and timeline from The Boss. Practical limitations – don’t ask me for the impossible! Design it! Findings Our company produces an array of high-quality products from which to draw inspiration for this new remote control: My solution: combination My solution: combination Components Outer casing Energy source User interface (i.e. buttons) Other alternatives? Transmission interface Infrared bulb Bulb Switch Energy source Wire Chip Subcomponent Personal Preferences Programmable options: Favourite channels Preferred volume settings Requires a small amount of memory Bells and whistles Require more money, effort More likely to work poorly ES2005docs.ES2005scen.participant3hBcInterface_concept..1.ppt ------------ Interface Concept Presented by: User Interface Designer Method Findings Personal Preferences ES2005docs.ES2005scen.participant3hBcTechnical_functions..2.ppt ------------ Technical Functions Design Presented by: Helen, User Interface Designer Method Look at existing designs What people like and dislike about certain products Search Internet for fashions/trends Ergonomics research- e.g. comfortable sizes shapes etc. Findings Basic Function of the basic remote: ‘to send messages to the television set’ These functions need to be included Effect they need to have is to e.g. turn on/off Current leading remotes are very boring Personal Preferences Something good to hold: tactile, not too ‘edgy’ Simple designs: easy to use, not too many buttons Size: hand held and portable. ES2005docs.ES2005scen.ProjectDocuments.Interface_concept,.user-interface.ppt ------------ Interface Concept Presented by: User Interface Designer Method Existing designs: their designs, why are they like that? good/bad features What do we need from the remote: easy-to-use buttons, layout of buttons etc. Findings Most remotes use graphical user interface; pictures as output, pointing device. Inconsistent layout New remotes: voice recognition, LCD displays (e.g. music download devices), mouse-like, child-friendly, over-sized,# Need to combine New speech recognition software!! Personal Preferences Raised symbols, makes remote easy to use LCD- fancy, looks smart; too complicated? Over-sized- gimmick, would it sell? Child-friendly- great idea, good shape; easy to use? Mouse-like- what do the scrolls work for? ES2005docs.ES2005scen.ProjectDocuments.Raj.--Evaluation--4.ppt ------------ Evaluation criteria Presented by: < Raj >, Marketing Expert Method User requirements Trends Marketing Strategy of the company Evaluation Criteria rating with seven-point scale ES2005docs.ES2005scen.ProjectDocuments.Raj.--Trend_watching--4.ppt ------------ Trend Watching Presented by: Marketing Expert (Raj) Method Methodology includes not only the recent remote control market survey but has also considered the latest fashion trends of the market. Findings Executive Summary Recent investigation of the remote control market shows the following: - The most important aspect for remote controls happens to be a fancy look-and-feel, instead of the current functional look-and-feel. This aspect is twice as important as the second aspect. - The second most important aspect is that a remote control should be technological innovative. In turn, this aspect is twice as important as the next aspect. - The third most important aspect is that the remote control should be easy-to-use.   Recent Fashion Update Fashion watchers in Paris and Milan have detected the following trends: - This year, fruit & vegetables will be the most important theme for cloths, shoes, and furniture. - Also in contrast to last year, the feel of material is expected to be spongy. ES2005docs.ES2005scen.ProjectDocuments.Raj.-Functional_requirements--2.ppt ------------ Functional Requirements Presented by: Ebenezer, Market Expert Method Asked 100 people what the thought about remote controls… We got a lot of complaints as there were open end questions We got some good reactions to specific questions Findings Bad Remotes are often lost (50%) Most buttons are not even used (50%) Takes too long to master (34%), etc. Good Most people between the age of 15-25 would love to have voice recognition. And want fancy pretty remotes. Personal Preferences Voice recognition exists already and is available as open source so there is no need to spend huge amounts in R&D. Yes it is sketchy at times but this is limited vocabulary. Kill 3 proverbial birds. People will buy it but is it practical and will they return it? What about visit\fors and training. ES2005docs.ES2005scen.ProjectDocuments.Minutes.of-functional-design-meeeting-of-real-reaction-design-team-on-26.doc ------------ Minutes of design evaluation meeting of real reaction design team on 26/01/05 at 1530 Present Brian(pm) Raj(m) Helen(uid) Arlo(ed) Followed agenda as per agenda(4).ppt Presentations Given by Raj to display evaluation criteria all ppt. presentations can be found in project documents folder evaluation of design showed a marked match with the evaluation criteria and the project was found to be within budget. ES2005docs.ES2005scen.ProjectDocuments.Minutes.of-meeting-of-real-reaction-design-team-on-26.doc ------------ Minutes of meeting of real reaction design team on 26/01/05 at 10:45 Present Brian (PM) Arlo (ID) Raj(M) Helen(UID) Followed agenda as per powerpoint presentation kickoff (in documents folder) Concepts agreed for new remote Range of colours / one for all (universal remote) Original design ES2005docs.ES2005scen.ProjectDocuments.Professional.Report.doc ------------ t 2003-2024 Aspose Pty Ltd. Real Reactions Phone 123 456 7890 12345 Main Street Telex 123 456 7890 South Ridge, WA 12345 Fax 123 456 7890 Remote Control Unit Design Report Design method The general design was carried out over four phases by four staff Project manager Brian Industrial Designer Arlo User Interface designer Helen Marketing manager Raj At each stage the project manager chaired the meetings and took notes for the minutes   Phase 1 was the functional design. This consisted of:   User Requirements Specification: what needs and desires are to be fulfilled Control Television Be easy to use  Technical Functions design: what effect the apparatus should have Control TV settings Working design: how the apparatus works to fulfill its functions Simple electronic board, LED   Phase 2 was the conceptual design. This consisted of:   Conceptual specification of components, properties and materials Conceptual specification of user interface Trend watching   Phase 3 is called the detailed design. This consisted of: Look-and-feel design User interface design Phase 4 Product Evaluation  At the end of each phase the minutes and presentations were produced and placed in the project documents folder.
